results.title: Louis IX, Roi, Chevalier et Saint = Louis IX, king, knight and saint
results.brief_description:
The eve of the XIIIth century marks the revival of royal power. In France, Louis IX models himself on Charlemagne and, just like his illustrious predecessor, has a chapel, La Sainte Chapelle, built to symbolise his authority and his role as a intermediary between man and God. During this period, Saint Louis participates in two Crusades in the Orient. Although a failure, the Crusades reveal to the Europeans a world much wider and more diverse than they ever imagined. With better boats, stirring and maps, Europeans are able to set off to far flung parts of the globe and bring back marvellous tales and exotic products. This is a time of discovery and optimism, reflected in a certain estheticism in art and where the beautiful primes over the demonstrative. The XIIIth century sees the creative impulse shift from France to Italy with its soaring class of merchants and bankers.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Cathedrale, la Ville, L'ecole = The cathedral, the city, the school
results.brief_description:
During the XIIth century, the centres of innovation are moving away from the monastries towards the cathedrals. Times are changing and what matters is now the secular world, the merchants and the bishop. Cathedrals are not simply devised for religious celebration, they are also civic centres where town meetings are held and to which the guilds of merchants contribute magnificent stainglass windows. During this period of urban revival, money flows towards the building of cathedrals in Reims, Laon, Chartres, Bourges, etc …

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Dieu et Lumiere = God and Light
results.brief_description:
The XIIth century sees Europe experience a steady growth in population and the consolidation of state entities. Money is being introduced in the circuit of commercial exchanges. In 1100, the abbey of Cluny is heralded as the most beautiful creation of monastic art and will soon be hiving off throughout Europe. Saint Bernard is highly critical of Cluny and its magnificence. He creates his owns congregation, the Cistercians. His vision of a simpler religion that casts wealth aside and renounces the world is reflected in the purity of the lines of the Abbaye de Fontenay. But the glory days of the monastries are numbered; the cities are emerging as new centres of power and authority. The cathedral is about to supplant the cloister. Other works profiled in this episode include: Moissac and Souillac (France), Pisa and Palermo (Italy), the cathedrals of Vezelay and Saint-Denis (France).

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: La Quete de Dieu
results.brief_description:
In a world almost empty of population and surrounded by the constant fear of war or invasion, small groups of people manage to erect magnificent churches. Northern Europe dominated by the heirs of Charlemagne lives the second blooming of classical Roman art. In the South, on the other side of the Loire river and the Alps, the culture and the landscapes are different. There is no central power or emmerging feudal system. The centre of power is the monastry where various experiments lead to a marked improvement in vaulting techniques. In the XIth century, religious buildings are built by paid labourers (the future guilds) but designed by clerics, “men both erudite and initiated into the mysteries. For them, considerations of perfect knowledge were to be found in numbers. And the highest human science was mathematics, closely linked to music and architecture. A romanesque church is at the same time an equation and a fugue.” Other works profiled include: the abbey of Conques (France) and the manuscripts of Gerona (Spain).

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: L'europe de L'an Mil = Europe in Year 1000
results.brief_description:
Europe in year 1000 is a wild and hungry world. Fields with poor yield are cultivated by slave labour, toiling in exchange for the protection of a local noble man. This period of history is still dominated by the figure of Charlemagne, emperor and divinity, intermediary bewteen heaven and earth, the visible and the invisible. The Palatine Chapel in Aachen (Germany), an octogonal building modelled on a Byzantine church, was to be his final resting place in 814. It remains a potent symbol of the wealth and power of the Carolingian dynasty. The influence of Byzantine art in Roman imperial art is also illustrated with the example of San Pedro de Roda (Spain). Other main works profiled in this first episode include: Tournus (Burgundy), the Bayeux tapestry, monastries of Reichenau, Echternach, Bamberg, Hildesheim and Liege.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Le Chapeau de L'empereur = the Emperor's Hat
results.brief_description:
Police chief Henry is working hard to have Vidocq promoted to head of Police Services. A few days before an official visit by Napoleon, the Police Museum is burgled and the Emperor’s hat is stolen. Flambard is designated to take the blame and resign, unless he can recover the precious hat before the visit. To do so, Flambart has no choice but to ask help from his old enemy, Vidocq.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Louis Arbessier, Gabriel Gabin, Robert Bazil, William Sabatier.

results.title: A vous de jouer, Monsieur Vidocq = Your turn Mr. Vidocq
results.brief_description:
Vidocq has an appointment with an old friend from Toulon. But by the time he arrives, his old friend is dead and the police holds Vidocq as the prime suspect.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Louis Arbessier, Marguerite Cassan, Claude Cerval.

results.title: Le Systeme du Docteur Terrier = Dr Terrier's System
results.brief_description:
The newly wed Vidocqs spend their honeymoon at Annette’s godfather’s. They receive a visit from strange characters whom Vidocq used to know when he was a convict in Toulon. They blackmail Vidocq into helping them with their forged money scheme.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Henri Cremieux, Jacques Dhery, Gilberte Geniat, Marion Loran, Harry Max, Jacques Seiler.

results.title: Le Marriage de Vidocq = Vidocq's Wedding
results.brief_description:
Vidocq and Annette would like to get married. They pay a visit to Jacquelin in order to chose a wedding ring. Caught in a random police raid, the pair narrowly escapes. Annette goes her own way while Vidocq seeks refuge with the ‘other’ Mrs. Vidocq.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Stephane Ariel, Eugene Berthier, Teddy Bilis, Christian Brocard, Leonce Corne, Jacques Monot, Henri Virlojeux.

results.title: L'auberge de la Mer Tranquille = the Inn of the Quiet Mother
results.brief_description:
Annette and Vidocq are enjoying a moment of rest at the Inn of the Quiet Mother. But their peace is disrupted by the arrival of a chain gang. The captain of the chain is Vidocq’s old ennemy, capitaine Thierry. Things take a turn for the worse when a convict recognises Vidocq.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Jacques Alric, Sacha Briquet, Marcel Charvet, Alain Janey, Dominique Zardi.
